results.title: A Life in the day of a cycle courier
results.brief_description: Sarah’s a cycle courier chasing the money, but at what price? Short and succinct this quirky little tale bounces along to the tune of “I Quite Like Girls on Bikes” written and performed by Urban Tramper and His Pack. Features Paige Anderson as girl on bike.

results.title: A Letter to Dad: a Story of Co-Dependency
results.brief_description: This program examines co-dependency. Reluctantly, Megan attends her uncle’s funeral, and in the company of her two cousins, revisits her childhood home. Witnessing Megan’s distress, her cousin encourages her to speak of the effects of her father’s alcoholism on her childhood. This conversation leads Megan to seek a therapist’s help, and during these sessions she realises the important role her past unhappy childhood has had in determining her life. She is eventually able to lay to rest all the anger, grief and guilt that she has been carrying for so long.

results.title: A Letter to Christopher
results.creator_credit: Artransa Park Studios and Kiwi Polish Company
results.brief_description: A classroom study of New Zealand’s native Kiwi - its appearance, habits and ancestry. It has been closely protected since 1908: its export is prohibited except on rare occasions, and it may only be kept in captivity for scientific studies. it has become a national emblem appearing on coins, incorporated in badges, and commonly used in referring to New Zealand’s people. Told by an Australian girl, Susan Boyden.

results.title: A Letter to Amy (K)
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel, Weston Woods Studios and Cynthia Freitag
results.brief_description: Tells the story of Peter, a young African American boy, who is planning his birthday party. Shows him pondering over the invitation letter and anxiously awaiting the party day to see if she comes. Concludes with Amy arriving very late, thus making the party a happy one.

results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Malcolm Otton
results.brief_description: No. 2 in the Junior Social Studies series this film shows how John, a boy who lives in Bathurst, New South Wales, receives a letter through the post from his friend Peter, who lives in Manly, Sydney, New South Wales.

results.title: A Lesson to us all
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face Australia”.
Outwardly, Japan is an economic and industrial giant, whose growth from the ashes of WWII into a powerful trading nation is a remarkable success story. This film looks at both sides of the Japanese story, contrasting the nation’s material wealth and manufacturing efficiency with the divisions created by changed social conditions, the tragic effects of uncontrolled pollution and pessimistic outlooks of concerned citizens.

results.title: A Lesson for teacher (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
In 1976 Dr Neville Bennett of Lancaster University published his research report evaluating the success and failure of various systems used in British primary schools. This was the first major attempt to analyse scientifically just how much children learn in establishments ranging from the most progressive, open-plan schools, to the most traditional. The publication of the report was an important educational event, and it will give rise to much questioning about the direction of current trends in British education. The report revealed that in one year pupils taught by formal methods can be as much as five months in advance educationally of those taught by the free style
